The beach ridges at Roddines are particularly well preserved. The beach ridges illustrate the uplift of the landmass during and after the last ice age. During the last ice age, both Scandinavia, Siberia and North- America was covered by ice sheets, and the world oceans were about 100 meters lower than today. Thus these areas, and Roddines, were located lower compared to sea level than today. As the ice started to melt, the sea level rose. At the same time the weight over land got smaller, and the continent rose as well, but faster than the sea. During periods of colder climate melting of ice stopped. When this happened the sea level and land rose at the same rate, and the waves had the opportunity to form the beach ridges.

You find the site along the path towards Ytrehornsnakken.
